Wins Iran's presidential election by a landslide, defeating Ayatollah Hashemi Rafsanjani.
Ahmadinejad gets approximately 62% of the vote and immediately begins stating his desire to restart Iran's nuclear program.
Sworn in as president.
During a speech at the World Without Zionism conference in Tehran, he states that "Israel must be wiped off the map."

Speaking to thousands of people in the Iranian city of Zahedan, Ahmadinejad states "Today, [Europeans] have created a myth in the name of Holocaust and consider it to be above God, religion, and the prophets."
Announces that Iran has produced low-grade enriched uranium that can be used for nuclear power.
One of two featured speakers on the opening day of the United Nations General Assembly.
The other is President George W. Bush.
The two men do not meet.
Speaks at Columbia University.
Ahmadinejad denies having ever denied the Holocaust, saying he just introduced "two questions" about it.
He is booed after saying "we don't have homosexuals [in Iran] like in your country."
Speaks to the UN General Assembly.
Christiane Amanpour interviews Ahmadinejad.
He unexpectedly gets up and leaves after only a few minutes.
Ahmadinejad visits Iraq; this is the first-ever visit to Iraq by an Iranian president.
He meets with Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki and President Jalal Talabani, discussing topics such as oil production and development, border demarcations, and Israel's excessive use of force in Gaza.
Is re-elected president of Iran as demonstrators fill the streets.
Is sworn in as president.
Arrives in Lebanon for his first state visit to meet with the president, the prime minister, and members of the militant group, Hezbollah, with whom Iran has a strong relationship.
Intelligence Minister Heidar Moslehi is fired by Ahmadinejad; the action is vetoed by the country's religious leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
Speaks at the UN General Assembly.
Ahmadinejad is summoned before parliament to answer questions about domestic and foreign issues.
Gives a speech at the United Nations, during which the ambassador from Israel walks out.
Hassan Rouhani
Rouhani is sworn in and Ahmadinejad officially leaves office.
State media reports that Ahmadinejad has registered to run in the country's presidential elections in May.
This is unexpected, as Ahmadinejad was instructed last September by Khamenei not to run.
The Guardian Council, a government forum that approves candidates, disqualifies Ahmadinejad from running in the upcoming presidential election.
